Agreed, map is cleaner than pushing to an array

May be worth just destructing the properties in the signature, saves the pattern of const {a,b} = props being repeated through the app.
const SettingsPage = ({ refreshUser, updateTemplate} = SettingsPageProps) => {
Can we just use 'type' here because 'SettingCategory' and 'SettingGroup' probably do not need inheritance and other abilities of 'interface' ?

It could be an option.
Generally I've seen type either used for managing primitive interfaces which can't be captured with interface or type projections (often using util types) which again aren't easily captured as interfaces.
What benefit do you have in mind for preferring type over interface in all cases?

Thanks @ChristianMurphy.  No, I am not preferring type. Yesterday, I  was confused about the mixed use of type and interface in this file: 
  
    
      openEQUELLA/Source/Plugins/Core/com.equella.core/js/tsrc/legacycontent/LegacyContent.tsx
    
    
         Line 33
      in
      903ca6b
    
    
    
    

        
          
           type LegacyContent = { 
        
    
  


For example, I did not work out why using interface for ChangeRoute and type for LegacyContent

Yeah, I suspect there is a fair amount of that, if we can get ESLint into the project (similar to #1234)
We could add https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/blob/master/packages/eslint-plugin/docs/rules/consistent-type-definitions.md to normalize this across the project.

#1234 has been updated, no errors, only a few warnings, if you want to review that.
Once it's merged can start exploring adding additional checks like https://github.com/typescript-eslint/typescript-eslint/blob/master/packages/eslint-plugin/docs/rules/consistent-type-definitions.md
If this is immutable then may be better have it declared outside the component body as it doesn't need to be re-evaluated ever

Help wanted !
Had a short discussion with Tom regarding the usage of this boolean flag. The intention is to avoid the warning:
Can only update a mounted or mounting component. This usually means you called setState, replaceState, or forceUpdate on an unmounted component. This is a no-op.
It seems a lot developers have accepted this approach, but I wonder if we have any better approaches.

An approach I've liked is wrapping network calls into hooks.
This allows things like cancellation on unmount, suspense support or loading states, etc.
There are some nice general purpose premade hooks like https://use-http.com and https://github.com/zeit/swr (or in this particular case https://github.com/mauricedb/use-abortable-fetch)
Or a hook could be written wrapping a network utility like https://github.com/sindresorhus/ky or https://github.com/axios/axios automatically doing cleanup on unmount.
Thanks @ChristianMurphy . Do you know if any of hooks mentioned above is used in oEQ ?

At this moment, no pre-built hooks or hooks packages are included in oEQ.
The utility function Axios is.

Hi @ChristianMurphy , would the Axios example be the cancel token?   We have some internal code implements it but I'm curious to know if there are preferable alternatives.

Yes, cancellation within Axios would be the cancel token https://github.com/axios/axios#cancellation
That could be wrapped as a react hook to automatically cancel on unmount.

I remember discussing this, it's interesting how it works and may be worth adding an inline comment to highlight it's to stop the setting state when component is being unmounted as it may get confused with a cancel token which it isn't.
May be worth discussing whether bringing in cancel tokens is a good pattern, as it'll cater for cancelling background API calls that won't be needed anymore, it may have covered preventing interacting with state when component is unmounting.
OK I will add an inline comment first. Later, we can discuss this with @edalex-ian
This has shown up a few times, a single function should be able to cover this (even if it does the same thing behind the scenes)
As discussed, once we have successfully setup Redux to handle errors in a centralised way, we can remove these handlerErrors. So keep it for a while.

I remember we had short discussions about the generic error handling in oEQ. This one looks generic but there is only one usage. openEQUELLA/Source/Plugins/Core/com.equella.core/js/tsrc/components/index.ts Line 10 in 903ca6b export function handleUnexpectedApiError

({

Personal preference, can this be function be moved outside of the component? (either a file or outside the component body) as it

makes the component body heavier
would be difficult to write a jest test for
Has there been any use of the Link component from Material UI?  It creates the same anchor but caters for styling from the MUI theme
Hi Tom, this is not a MUI Link. I think it's a react-router Link.

Sorry my question wasn't clear, it was more that the a hyperlinks may be better done as MUI Link as they will be tied into the theme rather than just be raw HTML links.  It will need an alias for the MUI link as it will collide with the router link
Else isn't needed, there's a return in the if
Is this div required?
I think so because quite a few Selenium tests need it.

Different minds for this but I'd avoid having extra elements that just drive tests, it's adding something to the DOM just a for a test whereas I'd expect extra attributes on real elements (things that are meaningful outside of functional tests) to support tests
Yup, definitely agree with that. But I'd prefer not to see this also trigger a whole lot of updates to tests. So for now, let's keep this as is, but not do this in the future. ;)
Should "ui" be a constant?  I don't know if it'll be used more than once
Can switch this to a jsdoc
Not sure on this but the settingsGroups function is going to be called on every render, the sorted and filtered groups may be better stored in state once

Can daisy chain the destruct or just destruct values from group.category as category is never needed and save needing to do category.variable again and again.
const { id, details } = group.category;

Is the Axios response ever needed?  If not then the results can be returned rather than the response, this will

save the caller from needing to know about Axios and means the underlying functionality can be switched to native fetch without impacting the callers.
allow callers to immediately destruct the result data in the then value without needing to do result.data

Also there's a lot of flipping between function and arrow functions, personal preference is to stick to one
export const fetchSettings(): Promise<GeneralSetting[]> => 
  Axios.get<GeneralSetting[]>(GET_SETTINGS_URL).then(resp => resp.data);
I've got mixed habits for JS docs between components and modules but I'm trying to get into the habit of adding them to modules, same as adding them on the java/groovy/scala side.

Not sure this div is needed
Without this div, the UI Setting Editor will look different. Therefore, some extra styles are required to ensure the UI consistency. So at this stage I am more inclined to keep this div.
By using MUI Grid we can remove this div.
There's no guarantee the error will be an AxiosError as the catch could return a runtime error
I think this can be achieved with a MUI Grid which will reduce the need for custom styles and cater for responsive design if desired at some point
Good idea.
I take it properties are injected into a component at a higher level, as routes has no contract for properties (e.g. component: "not valid" is fine and won't cause errors here)

import { Theme, ExpansionPanelDetails, List, ListItem, ListItemText, ExpansionPanel, ExpansionPanelSummary, Typography } from "@material-ui/core";
This could be a dedicated oEQ component, allowing it to  be defined once and potentially changed later without needing to update all the pages.

I have briefly discussed this point with Ian. It might be better that we create an oEQ component for CircularProgress  in another PR, and then we can replace current usages of CircularProgress with the new component.
Same as before, the MUI core components can be imported in a single line
I did not add cancel token here because cancelling this request will result in different user experience, and it is out of the scope of this PR.
Could useEffect and useState be destructured either on the import from react or at the beginning of the file?
Sure can.
